makers.displaydate: 1830–1903; born Charlotte Amalie, St. Thomas, US Virgin Islands, died Paris, France
makers.displaymaker: Camille Pissarro, 1830–1903; born Charlotte Amalie, St. Thomas, US Virgin Islands, died Paris, France

texts.textentryhtml:
1928, Le Garrec.

1938, Bequest of Dan Fellows Platt to Princeton University Art Museum

A decade older than Monet, Sisley, and Cézanne, Pissarro was the only painter to have shown in all eight Impressionist exhibitions  between 1874 and 1886. In 1884 he moved with his family from the suburbs of Paris to the picturesque village of Éragany, on the banks of the River Epte, Normandy. There, he immersed himself in the daily life of the local farming community, which became the primary subject of his paintings, drawings, and prints throughout the rest of his life.

bibliography.boilertext: Christopher Lloyd, "Camille Pissarro at Princeton," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 41, no. 1 (1982): p. 2–13.
bibliography.citation: Christopher Lloyd, "Camille Pissarro at Princeton," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 41, no. 1 (1982): p. 2–13., fig. 10, p. 7 (illus)
